Name: podrozniczka60
Title: Beautiful complex but no easy access. See it from the outside
Review: It is a distinctive and magnificent building complex. A true classic in its style and architecture. Best to see it externally. Between the intense traffic and the place being heavily guarded the direct access is practically impossible. Admire but from the outside

Name: NVKOnTheGo
Title: Better view on TV screen!
Review: The entire area is cordoned off and so we were not allowed to go anywhere near the building. The view from a distance didnt do justice to its grandeur. The visit was so poor that the BSF posted there even shoo off cars dropping the visitors. Things should be managed better and tourists shouldnt be shooed off like stray cattle!

Name: skagarwal74
Title: Nice evening visit
Review: The best way to reach here is to get down at Central secretariat metro station and walk down. The view at night is beautiful after the buildings are lit.

Name: sanjayvora45
Title: Circular in shape
Review: Edwin lutyens had designed this building in 1912, and construction was completed in 1927. It is believed that lutyens inspired by the design of the Chausath Yogini temple in morena dist. in Madhya Pradesh and incorporate the circular design.Very impressive building but only outside glimpse is possible as entry is restricted.

Name: annehA4231CL
Title: Evening visit
Review: We are arrived at about 6 in the evening and it was a quiet time to view the magnificence and scale of these buildings. We noticed a sign that a light show was to start at 6.30 pm and this covered the buildings in various hues of colour making it all the more striking. it is certainly one of the main sights to see, the grandeur of the architecture from colonial times and so at odds with the drama of other parts of the city.

Name: jjcoffman
Title: Enjoyed the architecture
Review: While in the area for India Gate, our driver drove us by so we could see the beautiful building. The flowers and areas near by make it a lovely spot.

Name: NafeeTA
Title: Architecture worth Viewing
Review: We didnt have much time on our hands so we just viewed it from the outside. However, the whole place is designed so majestically, very easy viewing on the eyes. It is very close to India Gate, so worth taking a stop to get a view if you are near that area.

Name: JP F
Title: Impressive but no need to spend a lot of time
Review: WE visited the parliament  house and walked around.  There is not much to do but worth look.  Just drive by...don't spend too much time

Name: Robert L
Title: Worthwhile
Review: A worthwhile to walk around when in Delhi, the morning view with the fog (which includes pollution) is an interesting time to visit.

Name: Sunil
Title: Indain Parliament
Review: The parliament is too huge and it's a indian pride.Early morning  this place looks good and the fog covers the place.Nice to watch

Name: guptahitendra
Title: Parliament House Museum
Review: Parliament House Museum is a nice place for our history and constitution. You can see here debate in Lok sabha and Rajya sabha. For entry passes are necessary.

Name: Dan L
Title: The Sansad Bhavan
Review: This is an impressive building, equally as impressive as the Rashtrapati Bhavan the former housing the Parliament and the latter, the President of India. It was constructed between 1921/1927. As with many other buildings and attractions, we had to be satisfied with a drive past on 7/10/19, barricading and armed security everywhere. Apparently it is possible to obtain a general entry pass if the House is not in session. Grandiose.

Name: israr mansuri
Title: Nice
Review: Indian parliament is one of the best place in India to know our history and lovely place it was .located in sansad Marg New Delhi

Name: A R Kohli
Title: India’s Lok Sabha and Rajya Sabha both Houses of Parliament
Review: This is an architectural beauty and a circular building. British had made it in 1920s. Both Lok Sabha and Rajya Sabha, members transact business here for discussions and former making laws for the Indian democratic Republic. You must spend lot of time to understand the working of this place. Amolak Rattan Kohli Former Governor of Mizoram

Name: Manoj Jain
Title: A seat of Power of the biggest democracy of the world
Review: The impressive round building is a treat to eyes. Done up in Victorian style speaks a volume about the seat of Power of the biggest democracy.

Name: JnVSydney
Title: Worth a look
Review: Probably not a stand alone attraction, as we could only do a drive past, however it was a very impressive Building (built by the british in the early 1920’s) to see, as it is the centre of the worlds largest democracy.

Name: theflyingdoctor
Title: Tour group drive oast
Review: Security is tight in this area for understandable reasons. Buses are not allowed to stop so 5his is only a drive past. Fascinating to be at the centre of the world’ largest democracy.

Name: Linda Y
Title: Sansad Bhavan
Review: Designed by British architect Herbert Baker for the Legislative Assembly, construction of circular Sansad Bhavan was completed in 1927. Today it houses the Indian Legislature, including the President, the Lok Sabha (House of the People) and the Rajya Sabha (Council of States). Historically the building is important because it was here that the Constitution of India was drafted. You’ll have to settle on viewing from a distance as sandstone railings prevent visitors from getting too close. On the day I visited, the road was still blocked off from the January 26 Republic Day celebrations.

Name: kattullus
Title: Circular building feeling quite modern
Review: Interesting circular building being a light coloured contrast  to the other official red sand stone complexes in the area with their formal majestic style.

Name: JEAN B
Title: Large impressive building
Review: Parliament house is a circular building where the Indian Parliament meets for sessions and functions. It consists of an open verandah with 144 columns and is surrounded by large gardens which are fenced off by sandstone railings. It’s architecture along with the other government buildings nearby is quite impressive. It was designed by the British architects Sir Edwin Lutyens and Sir Herbert Baker in 1912-1913. It is located in the north western side of the Vijay Chowk. We couldn’t get access the day we went as there were lots of police around moving you on because they were preparing for a special occasion. It is quite a large area to walk around all of the government buildings. It is open 11 am to 5 pm but closed on Sundays and Mondays.Depending on where you are it is easily accessible by tuk tuk or rickshaw (remember to haggle price as they do try to charge foreigners at least double what it should be.) Central Secretariat is the nearest metro and if you like walking India Gate is not too far away.

Name: Ethelberga H
Title: Only Good For a Drive By
Review: The Indian Parliament buildings Upper and Lower, are inaccessible and you cannot get very close. Our taxi mangaed to stop on the road side so we could take some pictures of these British Raj buildings but police are there to move you on. The buildings do look interesting but as you cannot go inside the visit seemed a waste of time.

Name: Annette A
Title: Interesting buildings, very spread out over huge grounds
Review: These government buildings are well worth seeing. You won't get very close, as security is tight, but the The Sansad Bhavan is the name of the House of the Parliament of India. This building contains the Lok Sabha and the Rajya Sabha located in New Delhi for both lower & upper houses of Parliament & is quite spectacular in size and setting amongst the grounds you can see from the road.The architecture of the Indian Parliament is impressive, and has history dating back to British era.The fountain in the midst of the main road plus the gardens and green areas of lush grass, make for a pleasant look at Delhi, after the normal street sights.Recommend to drive by & take a "look-see."

Name: durham05
Title: Can't get near
Review: Impressive buildings, built for the British Raj and now used as the national buildings. Interesting, but it's impossible to get anywhere near the main buildings. Would have been nice to explore this architectural masterpiece further.

Name: zesha123
Title: Corrupt
Review: I have no apprection for a place where corrupt politicians work in a country where it is difficult to make an official complaint about anything as they are so badly organised.

Name: 217bhatia
Title: TEMPAL OF DEMOCRACY
Review: From there india rule . This is the symbol of democracy . time or 15 august  or 26 jan its like golden vews. nearest metro station central secretariat walk in from there

Name: Christopher B
Title: Nice to see where our elected members work !
Review: The Parliament house is a cirular colonnaded building . It also houses ministerial offices,numerous committee rooms . It also has the meeting roooms for the Rajya Shabha , Lok Shabha and joint houses meetings.You need special permission to go into the Parliament house so try and get same if possible to get an inside view of where the indian democracy operates from.

Name: Sagar0111
Title: Parliament house - No one can forget
Review: Parliament house, is in itself historical monument. Its the made many years ago when india was not independent. Its a great feeling to see from outside as going inside needs some permission which is not easy to get. but then to seeing from a distance in itself is great. Everyone should go there atleast once in life time.

Name: GVB2011
Title: Very nice and clean place
Review: The parliament house was very very nice and clean with so many history related to  politics .I had a nice guide with me so I got to learn a lot about this place .. Definitely recommended for a history lover..

Name: Milan Patel
Title: Heart of the India
Review: Situated in the middle of the metro city Delhi. Connected well by the other part of the city. Infrastructure is totally mind blowing. Famous for all the activities regarding rajniti.

Name: Amolak Rattan K
Title: Seat of Indian Law Makers
Review: A beautiful circular building near Vijay Chowk is an architectural marvel . The Lok Sabha is the House of People And Rajya Sabha is the House of Elders and together they make Laws for the interest of people of India . It is a place worth visiting and one has to understand the strength of Indian Democracy .Amolak Rattan KohliFormer Governor of Mizoram

Name: Narayan V
Title: Amazing architecture
Review: Outstanding British architecture, crowded place - yet you can enjoy 2-3 hours easily.. security is very high here - sometimes they not allow to click pics as well...highly recommended

Name: dimpyrao
Title: Nice
Review: It is so beautifully in inner side for visit you have to take permission , and one gad will gied you and talk  about the history and famous thing about the Parliament house

Name: ranjanapathak
Title: Amazing architact
Review: In Parliament House Delhi, the Indian Parliament meets.  This is a massive spherical building. It comprises  three semicircular chambers-  Lok Sabha,  Rajya Sabha, and the library.  There is  27.4m high dome.  Architect of this building is  quite a feast for the visitors eyes.  The Entrance to outsiders is not allowed without official permission.  To enter the library, an entry pass can be obtained from the Visitor's reception. Entry and photography inside the Parliament is free with permission from relevant authorities.

Name: rohanpillai1
Title: Great
Review: An artistic achievement. This building is the working place of the politicians that govern the country. From an architectural point of view, the building is quite remarkable, unlike the members inside it. Do make sure to have a glimpse of it, if you're in Delhi.

Name: Anil1050
Title: Temple of Constituton
Review: Its a beautiful building, thoughtfully designed, and maintained. There is a good scope of illuminating it as per latest designs .Unfortunately, entry is not friendly because of security reasons.

Name: RobertFGCarter
Title: Huge complex
Review: Built for the Viceroy and designed by Lutyens, this complex is an architectural symbol of British domination up to 1947. Now used more appropriately by the President of India.

Name: mikesierra
Title: Worth a Drive Past
Review: A circular shaped building, Parliament House was principally designed by British architect, Sir Edward Lutyens, the main architect of New Delhi. It is adjacent to the President’s Palace and worth a drive past for a quick photo, as part of a tour of this New Delhi area.

Name: Scott8446
Title: Amazing
Review: This was my favourite place we visited in Delhi. The architecture was amazing and the symmetry was unbelievable. Would have stayed longer but was a little rushed by guide.

Name: Viral C
Title: Good place to visit
Review: It has completely different environment as being capital of India. It also gives proud feeling of being Indian

Name: TrevB56
Title: great buildings
Review: the symmetry of these buildings is pretty impressive - the two main buildings are like mirror images and even the ornamental pillars with the black ships atop fit into the symmetry. Usual opulence that you find for parliaments across the world - hopefully not as wasted on the local politicians as it is in some countries :-). Can see the Presidential Palace from here which is another massive complex of over 300 rooms (bet they have a cleaner lol)

Name: Rasheedur Rahman Shihab
Title: Prominent Building
Review: One of the few prominent buildings in the National Capital. I always have a dream to come to this place regularly by becoming a Member of Parliament.

Name: Richard H
Title: Large building
Review: Visited the parliament buildings as part of a Delhi tour. Interesting as the military were out practicing fro the Republic day celebrations.

Name: VBaheti
Title: Famous building of India
Review: - One should definitely go to this place where all major decision are made for the country and be a part of the sessions. - You need a pass to attend the Sitting. - it is a place where all the ministers elected for the national level gathered to take decision.- The food served in canteen of house was great in quality and quantity and delicious too at extremely low price. Had good experience.

Name: SinghCzar
Title: Imposing structure
Review: One of the very prominent buildings in Dew Delhi is the parliament house. This is where the Parliament meets for house business. It has expanded to house other amenities

Name: Kumar S
Title: Parliament House
Review: The architecture of the Indian Parliament is impressive and has history dating back to British era. It houses both the lower and upper house. Though this isn’t a tourist place, entry for common people is not allowed and is heavily guarded still a look from the drive around is worth.

Name: cagatravel
Title: Great area to view India's parliment buildings
Review: Not far from the India gate is the parliment of India buildings. Parliment house is a nice architectural building and there are many other political buildings and nice gardens and fountains  nearby to be viewed

Name: Paul R
Title: Grand, colonial leftovers
Review: The Parliament and surrounding buildings sit in an area of broad boulevards and expensive views in New Delhi, where they were built as an administrative district for the British Raj. Along with the India Gate archway at the other end of this long, broad road, they do present an imposing scene with historic significance as well as a stark contrast to the chaotic and claustrophobic jumble that makes up much of the rest of the city. It's worth a look for a few minutes as part of a tour of the sights, but I would not categorise it as a must unless that specific aspect of history is your particular interest.

Name: Mehdi_Farrokh
Title: Parliament House
Review: Parliament House is just a regular governmental building and we just visit it from outside. India has much too see and we could not reach all by visiting this one inside.

Name: kamakshi2015
Title: The historic seat of Governance !
Review: This is the most important place to look at if you are in Delhi . The imposing structure is a marvel of architecture and looks awesome ! . The governments who have functioned here and the decisions taken here for the entire India are well known . The tight security will prevent you from going close to it but , if there is a special permission obtained to view the proceedings it will give you the goose bumps !

Name: Kim K
Title: Impressive buildings built by the British
Review: These impressive buildings can be seen from a number of different sides when driving through New Delhi. Our driver drove up to the front but wasn't able to stop so we just had a very quick photo opportunity

Name: AndyMcGonegal
Title: Imposing Buildings but Generally only Seen at Distance.
Review: The most imposing of the buildings is the huge round Parliament building. Understandably, in the current threat climate, the area is pretty closely guarded and only really viewable at a distance.

Name: Leslie
Title: Pretty Building but Just a Drive-By
Review: Pretty from the outside and a lovely part of New Delhi but there isn’t much to see or do that you can’t do in photos. Just a quick drive by the buildings and you’re done.

Name: MusafirHarsha
Title: Temple of democracy
Review: Without a pass it is not possible to visit this high security place. Be content seeing it from outside. Nearest metro is Central Secretariat.

Name: jonahNJ
Title: The distinctive round building
Review: This building in some ways reminds me of the Pentagon in Washington D.C.  The obvious differences are that that Parliament House is the meeting place for india's legislature and is round; the Pentagon is the headquarters for the U.S. Military and have five sides. However, both have a unique shape, flat appearance and are centers of power in their respective countries. Parliament House is located near a lovely fountain that is a centerpiece in this complex of government buildings. However, much lije the Presidential Palace in Delhi, visitors may have limited time to visit this area, but it is worth a brief walk or drive around to check out the center of India's government.

Name: Traveller G
Title: As a citizen of India, I am proud of this building & area - Though, permission is needed to explore many areas!
Review: ##   The assembly place of the world's largest democratic Country Heads!##   Citizens and foreigners are allowed to see from outside, unless you have written permission for specific visit.##   Had been in the building for some specific purpose (Photography NOT allowed, except for permitted Media persons) - Huge and gigantic - hundreds of meters to walk to reach each block !##   Even the View & Photographs from permitted areas are beautiful ...!

Name: sawhneysaab
Title: Typical 'must visit'
Review: Must visit atleast once, to see for real what you see in books, on TV and on the back of 2000 rupee notes!

Name: s m
Title: This area is very structured.
Review: I always like to travel near this area as it is very structured, Green and clean. Seeing Parliament House on the way gives happiness.

Name: Peeyush P
Title: Awestruck
Review: The over-arching feeling as you go approach Parliament House in New Delhi is one of awe and wonder, since this is the place which is the fountainhead of the world's largest democracy. The architecture is quite interesting, and dominates everything else in the vicinity.

Name: Aman K
Title: Parliament house
Review: The Parliament house is more beautiful than the extent. It's beauty can attract anyone more. But the point of attention is that due to security, you will not be able to get in. It can be seen only from the outside.

Name: Anamika K
Title: The indian powerhouse
Review: The place where the country gets controlled. Visit this place only to add places in your visit list. Otherwise nothing great about this place. You can visit this place any time but my suggestion would be to visit this place when you go to visit India Gate because it is near it. So when you visit india gate don't forget to look a peek.

Name: Permpol
Title: Good walk for sunset
Review: I walked back from India gate through the public garden to metro . Spending time about 20 minutes then going metro,

Name: Ricardo R
Title: Not that interesting
Review: If you want to visit India Gate by yourself 100% sure you will use Central Secretariat metro station, this parliament house is beside the station, so take a chance and some 10 minutes to see and take some pictures.

Name: RadhakrishnanMS
Title: wonder ful architecture
Review: here also we only had a short stop for pictures and drive by ...was worth it ..the temple of democracy in India looks amazing

Name: Bik J
Title: It's worth spending a few minutes to take a picture
Review: we drove by and took a few snaps. We were happy with that. To be fair, I'm more interested in the ruins and the temples. Worth a look.

Name: LuckyJEDI
Title: Amazing architecture!
Review: The Parliament - like the Presidential Palace which is adjacent, is a spectacular structure.  I think more beautiful than our Capitol.  The gardens and grounds around the area are also lush and well-kept.  Worth a look.

Name: cg2792
Title: Beautiful area
Review: Really easy to see this from the nearby road. Vehicles cannot get too close due to terrorism risks but you can easily see the stunning architecture. If you have time I would recommend walking through the open green space that links the parliament building to the nearby India Gate.

Name: PCCS123
Title: Awesome Creation
Review: This building is located at Sansad Marg and this is the place where Indian President lives here. An awesome creation.

Name: Chandan P
Title: Good architecture
Review: The parliament house construction is very awesome. The architecture is good but we can't go near it due to the high level of security.

Name: Kumar S
Title: Parliament House
Review: The temple of the Indian democracy, both Lok Sabha and Rajya Sabha are part of the Sansad Bhavan. The Rashtrapati Bhavan and India Gate are near by, if have spare time do visit. The nearest metro is Udyog Bhavan.

Name: jonesharma29
Title: parliament house
Review: it is not a common building structure it is witness of many historical movement.parliament house is look beautiful but need permission for visiting some area.

Name: MarcinDrP
Title: It is a package.... and it sdepends as to what you like...
Review: Parliament buildings (both houses) and Presidential BUilding and the India Gate -- come as a package... if you see one; you will / should see the rest... Parliament buildings are definitely monuments from the past and worthy visiting if you like this kind of things...  it is all about your taste / interest....

Name: Jiju Mathew P
Title: Seat of Democracy
Review: A huge building royally built and sitting in the centre of the city. Couldnt go in and see had a view from out side reaaly magnificient

Name: Gavin R
Title: Up close for the 1st time
Review: Seeing the Parliament House was great. It was my 1st time being so close to the  centre of governance in the country. I wish I had the opportunity to go Inside the building.

Name: Edgar K
Title: nice building
Review: this is nice and new building, parks arround and walking area. place is central and you can reach many historical places by walking

Name: gentbrugg
Title: Endless repeatability
Review: I can't say that  I really liked the Parliament building (Sansad Bhavan). Rather, this endless outer colonnade (there seem to be almost one hundred and fifty columns) gives the building a kind of monotony. Considering that the size of the building is quite large – nearly 200 meters, the endless repetition of one element really bores down the eyesight. For my taste, this is the least successful work of the British architect, shaped the appearance of the official center of the city.

Name: Dusty Traveller
Title: Imposing Edifice, symbol of the largest democracy in the world
Review: The parliament House is an imposing and impressive structure, built in the Mughal style of architecture with glimpses of British colonial influence. The parliament house has strict security and one cant generally saunter in. However, drive around slowly around the area to get a good idea of its size

Name: Samar G
Title: Sansad bhawan
Review: The real name of parliament is "house of parliament". Inside the parliament everyone cannot take entry. parliament located near by india gate. last month i visited here with my friends  in evening. In evening the parliament looking gorgeous.

Name: GRAHAMMMCFARLANE
Title: Stunning building
Review: A highlight on our guided tour of the sub-continent was the Parliament House in New Delhi - the architecture is well worth the visit - highly recommended.

Name: Kirsty C
Title: Lutyens-designed masterpiece
Review: We only viewed from the outside, but it is well worth taking your time to visit this imposing building.

Name: KhalidNavigator
Title: Grand
Review: The parliament house is grand in its every bit. It leaves one in awe by its sheer size and magnitude.

Name: 268yusufn
Title: ULIMATE ARCHITECTURE
Review: The view of the Parliament is so amazing and feels awesome . We can even see the INDIA GATE looks  superb . Its one of the famous tourists spot.  Must Visit.

Name: KaranPais
Title: The place where India's members of Parliament debate
Review: Unfortunately, due to security concerns, visitors are not allowed inside. You can only drive by the outside of a certain section of the complex. Ironic, as an Indian citizen, I wasn't allowed into my country's Parliament House, but as a foreigner I was able to visit the British parliament in London.They do make exceptions, but you need a letter from a Member of Parliament.

Name: Carolyn N
Title: Drive-by of India's National Parliament
Review: These are impressive buildings with well-maintained gardens.We did not go inside and don't know if this is possible?

Name: YPK2013
Title: Interesting place to visit
Review: It is a memorable experience to visit the headquarters of our Democracy where laws are made. A must-visit place for tourists

Name: ax11111111
Title: impressive from a distance
Review: make sure you visit this part of the city - the scale is amazing and its beautifully kept. you can drive around  to see this and the india gate.

Name: MikeFJones
Title: Parliament House - For Local History Buffs only!
Review: Not a very recommended stop to stop by, Parliament House is a relatively new area built around 1920-30. Mentioned maybe in some tours, but not a real touristic spot: You cannot go inside nor even walk around it. You will be only allowed to see it from the distance, and shot won't be so good as you may think. Recommended only if you are nearby India Gate or Canopy Monuments. Avoid spending more than 10 minutes on this place and move to your next spot.

Name: pavrahi
Title: Open green grand and historic
Review: A very nice place to visit, unique historic place to see these buildings in Delhi. Very secured place.

Name: joanadventure
Title: Majestic & Grand
Review: This is among the best part of Delhi with good piece of architecture with clean .... Like all of the other presidential and ministerial buildings round here. The whole area is very majestic and grand.

Name: cazbatt
Title: Great building
Review: Like all of the other presidential and ministerial buildings round here Sansad Bhavan is a great piece of architecture. The whole area is very majestic and grand.

Name: HarshDharnidharka
Title: Dont miss out
Review: Do visit and see this place if time permits. Beautifully maintained and a peacefull place. Enjoyed our evening over there.

Name: Banshidhar S
Title: Parliment Building
Review: Parliament Building constracting began in 1921  and the third session of central legislative assemal wasthe house in 19 january 1927  .the shap in cirular  which based on the  ashoka chakra  separate  halls and centeral and new building

Name: zap r
Title: Political centre of the country
Review: 1. This place is closed on select dates, should check in advance.2. Very easy to access with public tranport.3 Not a fun site for kids.4. Can make it a round trip of 2hrs, which can include India gate,Rashtrapati bhavan n Parliament building as these place are close by.5 Free of cost, as entry inside is restricted.

Name: NIGELSWAFFER
Title: Worth a look as buildings are impressive
Review: You cannot enter but the outside is attractive with several officlal buildings in close proximity. Once again cars are not allowed to stop but you would be able to walk around easily ( although not able to get really up close) and our driver dropped me off and picked me up a little later once I had viewed and taken pictures. Near India Gate.

Name: Manfred1973
Title: Stroll along this area, away from honking drivers, masses of people and street-vendors.
Review: This area can be compared to the Washington Mall. You find a no-honking zone, widespread greenery, nice to look at buildings and just few people. It´s the complete opposite of old Dheli, and one can enjoy the tranquility and space. You can walk to the Gate of India from here.

Name: MohammadNejad
Title: not permitted to be visited closely
Review: in our way to Indian Gate we saw Parliament Building , we were told it is not permitted to stop and walk even around the building due to security condition . anyhow it was a beautiful building far from the bus,  no more.

Name: Michael L
Title: PART OF THE BRITISH HISTORY NOW HOME RULE
Review: This is part of the history when Britain was the rulers of the land.  Now this is the principle government seat  for the home rule of India.   See from out side,  no stopping due to security so walking by is the best.

Name: akjeth
Title: Democracy
Review: It houses both the Raj Sabha and the Lok Sabha where legislators meet in the Houses and debate on the various issues affecting the nation.

Name: Alan B
Title: Elegent Colonial Past
Review: India's Parliament Buildings are beautifully layout and are a great credit to India's colonial past. Well worth a quick look at and there is a great view back to India Gate from the Parliament Buildings.

Name: Punita S
Title: impressive
Review: impressive place to see and visit.  being an india, you feel proud to be around this place.  however, you cannot roam outside for longa nd there is lot of security who wont allow to stay around there unnecessarily

Name: AzadAjay
Title: Pride of the Nation
Review: Nice place to visit. Surrounded by many national importance places like Rashtrapati Bhavan including many ministries, Rajpath, India Gate, Secretariat and many more. Every Indian must visit alteast once.
